title: Is Your Diamond Loose? Here's How You Can Tell
text:
How to Tell if Your Diamond is Loose in the Setting Jamie Grill/Getty Images By Lauren Thomann My Diamond is Missing! How Did That Happen? 
One of my clients' biggest fears when buying an antique engagement ring is losing their center stone. I always assure them that the stones have all been tightened, but with older rings and with any age ring for that matter, unforeseen things can happen. It's difficult to pinpoint exactly what causes a center diamond to fall out. Sometimes the ring is poorly made, and sometimes a hard blow damages the setting. Sometimes stones fall out after a short period of time over seemingly nothing (which is why jewelry insurance is so important). Often times though losing a stone is due to general wear and tear on a ring that has not been maintained or properly cared for. When you lose a stone in your ring, the diamond is usually loose in a setting first and slowly works itself out. 
In order to minimize your risk of losing your center stone on your engagement ring or any other ring your wear often, it is important to have it professionally checked by your jeweler at least twice a year. They will check all the prongs and stones to be sure there is enough metal in place and all the stones are secure. More importantly though, it is good practice to check the stones yourself once a week or so. If you feel you hit your ring hard on something, check the stones immediately. Now this isn't something you have to do obsessively, and this is not meant to scare you. Rings, even antique ones, are durable and built to last, but being that they are commonly worn and our hands are constantly in and out of gloves, and rubbing up against things, it's important to be just a little bit more aware of your ring's overall condition. How to Check Your Center Stones 
Depending on the type of setting you have will greatly depend on which method you use to check the stone. If your stone is in a classic four or six prong setting, take the edge of your fingernail along the stones girdle (outward unpolished edge), and try to move the stone gently back and forth or up and down. If you cannot do this easily, your stone is likely secure. If your stone is bezel set or you don't have clear access to the girdle of the stone, then take a pin and gently press on the most outward point of the diamond. Try to move the diamond up and down or move the pin to the left or right to see if the diamond will move along with it. Don't be too aggressive with the pin because you don't want to do this so often and with such force that you actually cause your stone to become loose. Another easy test to do with any ring is to take the ring close to your ear and hold it snugly on the shank. Shake the ring back and forth and listen for any rattling sounds. 
If there is any movement in the stone or you hear any rattling noises, take the ring to your jeweler and stop wearing the ring until a repair can be done. How to Check Your Side Stones 
It's important when checking smaller side stones to be even more gentle and precise with your examination. I always use the pin test while wearing magnifying glasses. It's important to be careful because generally the accent stones have a lot less metal holding them into place than focal stones do, making them much more susceptible to becoming loose and falling out. Don't Press On Your Stones! 
One of the biggest mistakes I see people making with their rings is when they are putting them on and off. If the ring is a bit too snug, the tendency is to put one finger on top of the stone and one on the very bottom of the shank and pull. Try to resist the urge to do this. Take your rings on and off by placing your thumb and index finger on the sides of the shank so that you aren't putting any unneeded force on your stones.
